misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the provided loop logic correctly implements the required array right shift, where the elements are iteratively copied from index `i-1` to `i`, ensuring that data corruption is avoided by iterating backwards from the end of the array to the second element (index 1), and then assigning the stored final element (index n-1) to the first position (index 0).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap regarding the array manipulation here. The student has correctly identified the pattern required for an in-place right shift: save the element that must wrap around, then shift all other elements by iterating backward to prevent overwriting necessary source data before it is copied.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: None. The code produces the correct output according to the problem statement.
